comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Looks very like this house on Chaine Memorial Road.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A likely spot for an outing, as just behind the cameraman is the Chaine Memorial, a replica of a round tower, built in 1888.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Do you know what, but I think you're right! Have checked and checked structural features between both houses. Shame that the beautiful impressive wall and gate posts are gone now... And the Chaine Memorial is gorgeous too.

So, I'm adding this as a location, unless anyone else vehemently disagrees, and offers evidence to the contrary!  :)

Thanks a million, Niall
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: I think that Niall has hit the spot! To start ball rolling on the vehicle (buoyant on my successful input into the Martin family contraption), I would suggest that the car might be an 1890s Bristol.

comment.author: 72718192@N00
comment._content: It looks like the car is a Daimler 6hp twin-cylinder Six-seater it appears to of been in production between 1899 and 1901 [Wikipedia]

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: One of our NLI Facebook people has identified the gentleman with the impressive moustache in the front seat as Larne hotelier, Henry McNeill, and also reports that this vehicle was said to be Larne's first motor vehicle. We came across McNeill's Hotel in Larne before...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/kazzle101] You can see similarities alright in the overall design and the dating is right, but I'd be veering more towards [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward]'s suggestion of the Bristol. What does anyone else think?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: My vote is with the Bristol,the rear body seems to be a better match than the Daimler.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: So three votes for the Bristol; one for the Daimler! Any more?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 45785863@N06
comment._content: I would have put it down to a Daimler aswell, but it doe's look like more like a Bristol when you compare the photos. I wounder is there any connection with these photos on your online archive. Maybe this is a Daimler. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_1081 catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_1080

comment.author: 72718192@N00
comment._content: I'm now thinking its the Bristol too, because of the front grille. I have been searching newspapers of the period looking for the prices to compare the two, but cannot find anything. presumably if you have to ask, you can't afford it. Travelling exhibitions of Horseless Carriages look to of been popular at the time.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Reading that text, the Bristol company ran a kind of bus service using Daimlers before they built their first car, which wasn't until 1901, and that picture is 1890! I believe Mr. McNeill's car is a Daimler Wagonette, rather like the one Karl linked above. It's hard to be definite, as these cars were all essentially handmade, and many were altered later (for example, by adding a steering wheel instead of the tiller).

comment.author: 72718192@N00
comment._content: Am I allowed to change my mind back to the Daimler?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vintary] Ah now, that may really help. Both photos from our catalogue are of Mr Herbert Goff. He, like Henry McNeill, was the first in an Irish county to have a car - in this case, Waterford. We actually have a picture of Mr Goff and his car on here, but it's only recently that I discovered that in 1899, Goff "emulating the wealthy of Dublin among whom the elation of car travel was making life more exciting than ever, he created wonder among many who had never seen a motor car by driving his new Paris-built vehicle around the Quay. The owner of the first car registered in Waterford, his number plate WI 1 was retained in the family for many years." (from Irishmen or English soldiers? by Thomas P. Dooley, p. 14-15) Were Daimlers built in Paris?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/kazzle101] Of course you're allowed!  :D
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Daimlers were not built in Paris. The French pioneers of the motor trade were Panhard & Levassor. Which looks pretty good to me.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There was also Louis Fisson who was not only French, but from Paris.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Close... but some differences too! Is that because of the handmade factor?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Yes, I think each car was slightly different, and they also shared engines a lot, meaning cars from different makers might look alike!

I do think Mr. Goff's car is a Fisson, look at those sexy bent wood mudguards!
